case_vignette:
One week after undergoing sigmoidectomy with end colostomy for complicated diverticulitis, a 67-year-old man has upper abdominal pain. During the surgery, he was transfused two units of packed red blood cells. His postoperative course was uncomplicated. Two days ago, he developed fever. He is currently receiving parenteral nutrition through a central venous catheter. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. He is oriented to person, but not to place and time. Prior to admission, his medications included metformin, valsartan, aspirin, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows tenderness to palpation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding; bowel sounds are hypoactive. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocytes 13,500 /mm3
Segmented neutrophils 75 %
Serum
Aspartate aminotransferase 140 IU/L
Alanine aminotransferase 85 IU/L
Alkaline phosphatase 150 IU/L
Bilirubin
Total 2.1 mg/dL
Direct 1.3 mg/dL
Amylase 20 IU/L
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Gastrointestinal System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having upper abdominal pain, I've developed a fever, and I feel a tenderness when I touch the upper right part of my belly.
Have you had any vomiting or diarrhea?
No, I have not had any vomiting or diarrhea.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or eating habits?
I am currently receiving my nutrition through a vein.
Have you had any recent surgeries or procedures?
Yes, I had surgery a week ago where they operated on my lower left abdomen and gave me an opening for my stool to leave my body.
Have you been taking any medications for your condition?
Yes, I was taking medicine for sugar in my blood, blood pressure, thinning my blood, and cholesterol before coming to the hospital.
Have you had any family history of similar conditions?
I'm just a patient; I don't have any information about my family's medical history to share.
Final Diagnosis: Postoperative Complication

The patient is currently receiving nutrition through a vein and has undergone surgery on the lower left abdomen a week ago. Medications for blood sugar, blood pressure, blood thinning, and cholesterol were being taken prior to hospitalization. The patient does not have any information about their family's medical history to share.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is acalculous cholecystitis.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis in this patient is cholangitis.
